data.title: Catalog
data.meta_description: Fanchon lives in the forest with her grandmother, Old Fadette, who is reputed to be a witch. The girl is snubbed by the local children because of her grandmother's reputation and her own unkempt appearance, but she gets her revenge by playing pranks on them. At a May Day picnic, Fanchon initially frightens and then intrigues Landry Barbeau, the son of a wealthy merchant. After Fanchon saves Landry's brother, Didier, from mistreatment and rescues Landry himself from drowning, the young man tells his parents that he loves Fanchon and ends his engagement to the priggish Madelon. Although she longs for love, Fanchon proudly tells Landry she will not marry him unless his father asks her. While Landry is away for a year, Old Fadette dies and Fanchon is left alone. When he returns and develops a serious fever, his parents invite Fanchon to visit. Her presence leads to Landry's recovery, and his father begs Fanchon to marry his son.
data.text:
The scenario was based on the 1849 novel La Petite Fadette, by George Sand, a pseudonym for French writer Amantine Lucile Aurore Dupin, or Mme. Dudevant. The screen adaptation starring Mary Pickford was announced in the 1 May 1915 Motography. A general release was scheduled for 10 May 1915. The 12 Jun 1915 Pictures and the Picturegoer noted that the film marked Pickford’s first screen appearance with both of her siblings, Lottie and Jack Pickford. Various sources have credited Frances Marion with either writing or contributing to the scenario.

Fanchon the Cricket opened during the week of 10 May 1915 at the Strand Theatre in New York City, and at Orchestra Hall in Chicago, IL. Later that year, the 18 Dec 1915 Moving Picture World reported that the film was included in a week-long tribute to Pickford at the Carlton Theatre in her hometown of Toronto, Canada.

According to the Library of Congress American Silent Feature Film Survival Database, this film is extant.

Independent Moving Pictures Co. of America (IMP), later known as Universal Film Mfg. Co., released a short subject titled Fanchon the Cricket on 17 Jun 1912. ...

More Less

The scenario was based on the 1849 novel La Petite Fadette, by George Sand, a pseudonym for French writer Amantine Lucile Aurore Dupin, or Mme. Dudevant. The screen adaptation starring Mary Pickford was announced in the 1 May 1915 Motography. A general release was scheduled for 10 May 1915. The 12 Jun 1915 Pictures and the Picturegoer noted that the film marked Pickford’s first screen appearance with both of her siblings, Lottie and Jack Pickford. Various sources have credited Frances Marion with either writing or contributing to the scenario.

Fanchon the Cricket opened during the week of 10 May 1915 at the Strand Theatre in New York City, and at Orchestra Hall in Chicago, IL. Later that year, the 18 Dec 1915 Moving Picture World reported that the film was included in a week-long tribute to Pickford at the Carlton Theatre in her hometown of Toronto, Canada.

According to the Library of Congress American Silent Feature Film Survival Database, this film is extant.

Independent Moving Pictures Co. of America (IMP), later known as Universal Film Mfg. Co., released a short subject titled Fanchon the Cricket on 17 Jun 1912.

Less

Although she longs for love, Fanchon proudly tells Landry she will not marry him unless his father asks her. While Landry is away for a year, Old Fadette dies and Fanchon is left alone. When he returns and develops a serious fever, his parents invite Fanchon to visit. Her presence leads to Landry's recovery, and his father begs Fanchon to marry his son. ...
